monogr.title: Caltha poetarum: or The bumble bee. Composed by T. Cutvvode Esquyre

div.head: TO THE CONCEITED Poets of our age.
div.p:
SCribimus indocti docti{que} poëmata passim. Pardon me Gentlemen & others that delight to write, if out of my own humor & knowledge of my selfe, I deliuer this cōceit before my booke, that all wee write is but conceit. And nothing pleaseth conceited mē more then to haue partners or acquaintances with their conceits. Scire tuum nihil
est nisi, quod scis hoc sciat alter. Be it learned or not, yet the contriuing pleaseth the humor, so the subiect be drawne out of the sweete impressiō of content. Being contriued, partialitie breeds either such pittie, that the houres spent to our pleasure, should be blotted with obliuion, or such hopes, that what we write, may meete with like affected humors, which may receiue it vvith some liking, as vve die if vve offer not the vvorld our conceits. The end is to our vvritings that are vnlearned, al one, as to the learnedst Poems that are. For Homer, vvho immitated none, and
Archilocus, who is compared with Homer, because they only finished their workes in their life. And Virgil, the curious Ape of Homer. Ouid the Amorous, Martiall the lycentious, Horace, the mixt betwixt modest & Satirique vaine. The flower of our age, sweete pleasing Sidney. Tasso the graue. Pollished Daniel the Historick. Spencer the Truthes Faith. All these haue this only vsury of their pains, they please others & thēselues. In like maner, as we please our selues, so some are pleased with vs. For as these are admired & deified almost by the wisest, the lernedst, & the deepest sighted
into great matters, the ignorant not being able to attaine vnto thē. So we are held among the inferior spirits, and are the litle Penates, to countrey, homely and lowe reaching wits, admired by such, and religiously read, though neuer takē into the others hands. Are they then knowne? So are we. Are they not knowne to all? No more are we. Do they carp and iest at vs, if by chāce we fall into their fingers? Wee will crie quittance, for wee wil not vnderstand them in some things, and touch them with an Ironicall Adage; Quae supra nos nihil ad nos. Gentlemen & others, I pray
you let vs holde together for the preseruatiō of our reputation, and maintain the prescription of our lowe subiects, least Apollos musick do quite drowne poore Pan, and the countrey Hornpipe be laid aside. Alas, if the woods, the poore brooks, and the dales of the countrey, sound not sometime in our eares, as well as the Prince of Riuers, let the lasses giue ouer laaking in the greene, and dauncing about the Maypole. It were great pittie the little Cupids Altars should bee altogither defaced, from whose euer renuing influence, so many pleasing subiects doo flowe into
our brains. For whilst he cōtinues honored in the world, wee must once a yeare bring him vpon the stage, either dācing, kissing, laughing, or angry, or dallying with his darlings, leaping into their eyes, seating himself in their breasts, cōmanding more then imperiously all the gods; or crying for childish peeuishnes; or metamorphosed into many chāgeable shapes; or playing in a gardē as I do at this time; weeping, and againe stung with a Bee. There is a secret (but, I may not reueale the counsels & secrets of our state of loue) which makes this young god, be to all men the
plain song to their descant of their In Nomines. It cannot be youth alone, for then old men could not dote, and young men might only claime priuiledge of loue frō the the God. What should it then be? Surely, if not a secret influence in the beloued, I cannot diuine the reason. For if aged Trees were not succoured with the Sun as well as yong plants, their decay would be sudden. All sorts do offer sacrifice to him. Let all sortes then be retained, deuoutly in the opinion of deuotion. For the aged no sooner laught the yong man to scorn for louing, but straightly hee doated.
Let me I pray you abruptly thus end, least I speak too much, when I doubt my speech will onely please my owne conceit.
